name: Katalin Novak-Szenasi
summary: Katalin Novak-Szenasi is a Hungarian biochemist who contributed to enzyme inhibitor research and pharmaceutical chemistry in Central Europe. Her work on protease inhibitors advanced drug development for inflammatory and cardiovascular diseases. She helped build Hungary's pharmaceutical research infrastructure.

name: Tadeus Reichstein
summary: Tadeus Reichstein was a Polish-Swiss chemist who shared the 1950 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering cortisone and other adrenal cortex hormones. He also independently developed a process for synthesizing vitamin C (the Reichstein process), which remains the basis for industrial vitamin C production today.
timeline: Developed industrial vitamin C synthesis (Reichstein process)
Became professor at University of Basel
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Daniel Bovet
summary: Daniel Bovet was a Swiss-born Italian pharmacologist who won the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for developing the first antihistamine drugs and synthetic curare compounds. His antihistamines revolutionized the treatment of allergies, and his muscle relaxants transformed surgical practice by enabling safer anesthesia.
timeline: Moved to Istituto Superiore di Sanità, Rome
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Mario Capecchi
summary: Mario Capecchi is an Italian-born American geneticist who shared the 2007 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for developing techniques to create gene knockout mice. His gene targeting technology enables scientists to disable specific genes in mice, revolutionizing the study of gene function and disease. He survived homelessness as a child in war-torn Italy.
timeline: Became homeless war orphan, lived on streets
Reunited with mother, moved to the United States
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Christiane Nusslein-Volhard
summary: Christiane Nüsslein-Volhard is a German developmental biologist who shared the 1995 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the genetic control of early embryonic development. Her systematic screening of Drosophila mutations identified the key genes that control body plan formation in all animals, transforming developmental biology.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tübingen
Published landmark paper on embryonic patterning genes
Joined Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Elizabeth Blackburn
summary: Elizabeth Blackburn is an Australian-American molecular biologist who shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering telomerase, the enzyme that maintains telomeres at chromosome ends. Her work revealed that telomere shortening is linked to aging and cancer, opening new avenues for anti-aging and cancer research.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Cambridge
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Jack Szostak
summary: Jack Szostak is a British-Canadian-American biologist who shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering how chromosomes are protected by telomeres and telomerase. He also conducts groundbreaking research on the origin of life, synthesizing protocells that can grow and divide, attempting to recreate the earliest forms of life.
timeline: Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Carol Greider
summary: Carol Greider is an American molecular biologist who co-discovered telomerase as a graduate student working with Elizabeth Blackburn in 1984. She shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. She demonstrated that telomerase adds DNA repeats to chromosome ends, explaining how chromosomes maintain their integrity through cell division.
timeline: Began graduate work with Elizabeth Blackburn at UC Berkeley
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Craig Venter
summary: Craig Venter is an American biologist who led the private effort to sequence the human genome, competing with the public Human Genome Project. In 2010, his team created the first synthetic organism (Mycoplasma mycoides JCVI-syn1.0) by synthesizing an entire bacterial genome and transplanting it into a cell. He founded Celera Genomics and the J. Craig Venter Institute.
timeline: Born in Salt Lake City, Utah
Left NIH to found The Institute for Genomic Research
Founded Celera Genomics for human genome sequencing
Celera completed draft human genome simultaneously with HGP
Published first complete individual human genome

name: Eric Lander
summary: Eric Lander is an American geneticist and mathematician who was one of the leaders of the Human Genome Project and founding director of the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. A former mathematician, he developed computational methods for gene mapping and was instrumental in sequencing the human genome. He briefly served as White House science advisor.
timeline: Earned PhD in mathematics from Oxford
Became leader in Human Genome Project

name: Svend Funder
summary: Svend Funder is a Danish geologist and glaciologist who has studied the history of Greenland's ice sheet and its response to past climate changes. His research on ancient sediments beneath the Greenland ice sheet has revealed that Greenland was ice-free more recently than previously thought, with implications for understanding future sea level rise.
timeline: Studied ice sheet history through sediment cores
Published findings on ancient Greenland environment
Advanced understanding of ice sheet dynamics

name: Wallace Broecker
summary: Wallace Broecker was an American geochemist who popularized the term 'global warming' in a 1975 scientific paper and discovered the ocean's thermohaline circulation ('great ocean conveyor belt'). His research showed how the ocean controls climate and how rapid climate change can occur. He was one of the most influential climate scientists of the 20th century.
timeline: Published 'How to Build a Habitable Planet'

name: Willi Dansgaard
summary: Willi Dansgaard was a Danish paleoclimatologist who pioneered the use of oxygen isotope ratios in ice cores to reconstruct past climates. He discovered the Dansgaard-Oeschger events, rapid climate oscillations during the last ice age. His ice core analysis methods became the foundation of polar climate research and transformed our understanding of climate history.
timeline: Discovered relationship between isotopes and temperature
First deep ice core drilling at Camp Century, Greenland
Published first ice core climate record

name: Syukuro Manabe
summary: Syukuro Manabe is a Japanese-American meteorologist who shared the 2021 Nobel Prize in Physics for developing the first reliable climate models that demonstrated the link between CO2 levels and global warming. His 1967 model showing how increased CO2 in the atmosphere leads to increased temperatures was a landmark in climate science.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo

name: Klaus Hasselmann
summary: Klaus Hasselmann is a German physicist and oceanographer who shared the 2021 Nobel Prize in Physics for identifying the fingerprints of human-caused climate change in observational data. He developed methods to distinguish natural climate variability from human influence, providing scientific proof that global warming is caused by human CO2 emissions.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Göttingen
Founded Max Planck Institute for Meteorology
Published methods for detecting human influence on climate

name: Michael Mann
summary: Michael Mann is an American climatologist who co-created the 'hockey stick' graph showing that recent global temperatures are unprecedented in the last 1,000 years. His multiproxy temperature reconstruction became an iconic symbol of climate change science and was featured in the IPCC Third Assessment Report. He has been a vocal advocate for climate action.
timeline: Hockey stick featured in IPCC Third Assessment Report
Published 'The Hockey Stick and the Climate Wars'

name: Vilhelm Bjerknes
summary: Vilhelm Bjerknes was a Norwegian physicist and meteorologist who founded the Bergen School of Meteorology and laid the foundations of modern weather forecasting. He proposed that weather prediction should be based on the laws of physics and thermodynamics rather than empirical rules. His polar front theory explained the formation of weather fronts and cyclones.
timeline: Developed polar front theory with son Jacob

name: Svante Arrhenius
summary: Svante Arrhenius was a Swedish physicist and chemist who won the 1903 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his electrolytic theory of dissociation. In 1896, he was the first scientist to calculate how CO2 influences Earth's temperature through the greenhouse effect, predicting that doubling CO2 would raise global temperatures by 5-6°C — remarkably close to modern estimates.
timeline: Calculated CO2 greenhouse effect on temperature
Published 'Worlds in the Making' on climate

name: James Hutton
summary: James Hutton was a Scottish geologist known as the 'Father of Modern Geology.' He proposed the theory of uniformitarianism — that the same geological processes operating today have operated throughout Earth's history. His concept of 'deep time' showed that Earth is immensely old, challenging biblical chronology and revolutionizing geology.
timeline: Earned medical degree from Leiden University
Presented uniformitarianism to Royal Society of Edinburgh

name: Charles Lyell
summary: Charles Lyell was a British geologist whose Principles of Geology popularized Hutton's uniformitarianism and established geology as a modern science. His work profoundly influenced Charles Darwin's thinking about biological evolution. He demonstrated that geological features form through gradual, ongoing processes rather than catastrophic events.
timeline: Studied geology under William Buckland at Oxford
Published Geological Evidences of the Antiquity of Man

name: Mary Leakey
summary: Mary Leakey was a British paleoanthropologist who made several of the most important fossil discoveries in human evolution. She discovered the Zinjanthropus skull at Olduvai Gorge (1959), the Laetoli footprints showing bipedal walking 3.6 million years ago (1978), and Proconsul africanus. Her fieldwork in East Africa transformed understanding of human origins.
timeline: Began fieldwork in East Africa with Louis Leakey

name: Luis Alvarez
summary: Luis Alvarez was an American experimental physicist who won the 1968 Nobel Prize in Physics for developing the hydrogen bubble chamber. He and his son Walter famously proposed the asteroid impact theory for the extinction of dinosaurs in 1980, based on the iridium anomaly at the K-T boundary. He held over 40 patents.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
Contributed to radar development at MIT
Flew as observer on Hiroshima bombing
Proposed asteroid impact caused dinosaur extinction

name: Walter Alvarez
summary: Walter Alvarez is an American geologist who, with his father Luis, proposed the asteroid impact theory for the extinction of the dinosaurs in 1980. Their discovery of anomalously high iridium levels in the K-T boundary clay suggested a massive asteroid impact 66 million years ago. The Chicxulub crater was later found in Mexico, confirming their theory.
timeline: Discovered iridium anomaly in Italian K-T boundary clay
Published asteroid impact extinction theory with father
Published 'T. rex and the Crater of Doom'

name: Katsuko Saruhashi
summary: Katsuko Saruhashi was a pioneering Japanese geochemist who developed the first method to measure CO2 concentration in seawater. She tracked radioactive fallout in the Pacific Ocean from nuclear testing and proved that nuclear contamination was spreading globally through ocean currents. She was the first woman to earn a doctorate in chemistry in Japan and established prizes for women scientists.
timeline: Earned first chemistry doctorate by a Japanese woman
Tracked radioactive fallout in Pacific Ocean
Proved global spread of nuclear contamination
Established Saruhashi Prize for women scientists

name: Sau Lan Wu
summary: Sau Lan Wu is a Chinese-American particle physicist who has been involved in three of the most important particle physics discoveries: the J/psi particle (1974), the gluon (1979), and the Higgs boson (2012). She is a professor at the University of Wisconsin and has been a key experimenter at CERN. Her persistence across decades of high-energy physics is remarkable.
timeline: Key role in gluon discovery at DESY

name: Mária Telkes
summary: Mária Telkes was a Hungarian-American physicist who was one of the pioneers of solar energy technology. She developed the first solar-heated house (Dover Sun House, 1948), a solar-powered water desalination system for the US military, and solar ovens for developing countries. Known as the 'Sun Queen,' she held over 20 patents in solar technology.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Budapest
Developed solar water desalination for military
Built first solar-heated house with Eleanor Raymond
Invented solar oven for developing countries

name: Hedy Lamarr
summary: Hedy Lamarr was an Austrian-American actress and inventor who co-invented spread spectrum technology with composer George Antheil in 1942. Their frequency-hopping system, originally designed to prevent torpedo radio guidance jamming, became the basis for modern Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and cellular communications. She was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame in 2014.
timeline: Patented secret communication system with Antheil
US Navy adopted technology for Cuban Missile Crisis
Inducted into National Inventors Hall of Fame

name: Stephanie Kwolek
summary: Stephanie Kwolek was an American chemist who invented Kevlar, the super-strong synthetic fiber that is five times stronger than steel by weight. Working at DuPont in 1965, she noticed unusual properties in a polymer solution that became the basis for Kevlar, which is used in bulletproof vests, tires, boats, and aerospace applications. It has saved thousands of lives.
timeline: Inducted into National Inventors Hall of Fame
Inducted into National Women's Hall of Fame

name: Ada Yonath
summary: Ada Yonath is an Israeli crystallographer who shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for determining the atomic structure of the ribosome using X-ray crystallography. Her work revealed how the ribosome translates genetic information into proteins, enabling the design of improved antibiotics. She was the first Israeli woman to win a Nobel Prize.
timeline: Born in Jerusalem, British Mandate of Palestine

name: Tu Youyou
summary: Already covered earlier. Duplicate check.

name: Rita Levi-Montalcini
summary: Rita Levi-Montalcini was an Italian neurobiologist who discovered nerve growth factor (NGF), sharing the 1986 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. She conducted groundbreaking experiments in a home laboratory during WWII, when she was barred from academia by fascist racial laws. She remained scientifically active until age 103, the longest-lived Nobel laureate.
timeline: Earned medical degree from University of Turin
Banned from academia by fascist racial laws
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Dorothy Hodgkin
summary: Dorothy Hodgkin was a British chemist who won the 1964 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for determining the structures of important biochemical substances using X-ray crystallography. She solved the structures of penicillin (1945), vitamin B12 (1954), and insulin (1969). She was the first British woman to win a Nobel Prize in science.

name: Gertrude Elion
summary: Gertrude Elion was an American biochemist who shared the 1988 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for developing drugs through rational drug design rather than trial-and-error. She developed the first drugs for treating leukemia, malaria, organ transplant rejection (azathioprine), and herpes (acyclovir). Her work saved millions of lives.
timeline: Earned master's from New York University
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
Died in Chapel Hill, North Carolina

name: Rosalyn Yalow
summary: Rosalyn Yalow was an American medical physicist who shared the 1977 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for developing radioimmunoassay (RIA), a technique that uses radioactive isotopes to measure tiny amounts of biological substances in blood. RIA revolutionized diagnostics by enabling detection of hormones, viruses, vitamins, and drugs at concentrations previously undetectable.
timeline: Born in The Bronx, New York City
Earned PhD from University of Illinois
Began research at VA hospital with Solomon Berson
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Linda Buck
summary: Linda Buck is an American biologist who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Richard Axel for discovering the odorant receptor gene family and elucidating the organization of the olfactory system. Her work revealed how 1,000 different receptor genes enable humans to detect and discriminate approximately 10,000 different odors.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Texas
Joined Richard Axel's lab at Columbia
Joined Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: May-Britt Moser
summary: May-Britt Moser is a Norwegian neuroscientist who shared the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering grid cells in the brain's entorhinal cortex. Grid cells form a coordinate system that enables spatial navigation. Together with her then-husband Edvard Moser, she revealed how the brain creates maps of space.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Oslo
Joined Norwegian University of Science and Technology
Co-founded Kavli Institute for Systems Neuroscience
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Donna Strickland
summary: Donna Strickland is a Canadian physicist who shared the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physics for developing chirped pulse amplification (CPA), a technique for generating high-intensity ultrashort optical pulses. She was only the third woman in history to win the Physics Nobel. CPA is used in laser eye surgery, industrial machining, and particle physics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Rochester
Co-developed chirped pulse amplification with Gérard Mourou

name: Andrea Ghez
summary: Andrea Ghez is an American astronomer who shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering a supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy. Using adaptive optics to observe stars orbiting Sagittarius A*, she proved the existence of a compact object with a mass of four million suns. She was the fourth woman to win the Physics Nobel.
timeline: Published first evidence of supermassive black hole at galactic center
Tracked stellar orbits around Sagittarius A*

name: Maria Goeppert Mayer
summary: Maria Goeppert Mayer was a German-American physicist who won the 1963 Nobel Prize in Physics for proposing the nuclear shell model. Her model explained why certain numbers of nucleons (magic numbers) result in especially stable nuclei. She was the second woman to win the Nobel Prize in Physics (after Marie Curie) and developed two-photon absorption theory.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Göttingen

name: Wu Jianxiong
summary: Already covered - duplicate check for Chien-Shiung Wu.

name: Grace Hopper
summary: Grace Hopper was an American computer scientist and US Navy rear admiral who developed the first compiler for a computer programming language and was instrumental in developing COBOL. She coined the term 'debugging' after finding an actual moth in a computer. Known as 'Amazing Grace,' she was one of the most influential figures in computing history.
timeline: Earned PhD in mathematics from Yale
Programmed Mark I computer at Harvard
Led development of COBOL programming language
Retired as rear admiral at age 79

name: Katsuyuki Shirai
summary: Katsuyuki Shirai is a Japanese roboticist and AI researcher who has contributed to the development of intelligent robotics and computer vision systems at Osaka University. His research on visual recognition and manipulation has advanced Japan's leadership in industrial and service robotics.

name: Hyun-Chul Kim
summary: Hyun-Chul Kim is a Korean roboticist at KAIST who has contributed to the development of humanoid robots and robotic systems for disaster response. His work on the HUBO humanoid robot helped Korea win the DARPA Robotics Challenge in 2015, demonstrating Korea's capabilities in advanced robotics.
timeline: Developed HUBO humanoid robot at KAIST
KAIST team won DARPA Robotics Challenge

name: Oh Jun-Ho
summary: Oh Jun-Ho is a Korean mechanical engineer and roboticist at KAIST who led the development of the HUBO humanoid robot series and DRC-HUBO, which won first place at the 2015 DARPA Robotics Challenge. His team's victory made Korea a world leader in humanoid robotics for disaster response.
timeline: Earned PhD in mechanical engineering from UC Berkeley

name: Shankar Balasubramanian
summary: Shankar Balasubramanian is a British chemist of Indian origin who co-invented Solexa sequencing (now Illumina next-generation sequencing), which has been used to generate over 90% of all DNA sequencing data worldwide. His technology made genome sequencing thousands of times cheaper and faster, enabling personalized medicine and genomic research.
timeline: Received Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences

name: Feng Kang
summary: Feng Kang was a Chinese mathematician who independently developed the finite element method in 1965, around the same time as Western mathematicians. His method for solving partial differential equations became fundamental to engineering simulation and computational science. He also developed symplectic algorithms for Hamiltonian systems. He is considered the father of Chinese computational mathematics.
timeline: Earned PhD from Steklov Mathematical Institute, Moscow

name: Ismail al-Jazari
summary: Already covered - see Al-Jazari entry. Duplicate check.

name: Hypatia
summary: Hypatia of Alexandria was a Greek-Egyptian mathematician, astronomer, and philosopher who was the head of the Neoplatonic school in Alexandria. She was one of the greatest scholars of the ancient world, contributing to mathematics and astronomy, and is considered the first notable woman mathematician. She was murdered by a Christian mob in 415 AD.
timeline: Murdered by Christian mob in Alexandria

name: Hildegard of Bingen
summary: Hildegard of Bingen was a German Benedictine abbess and polymath who wrote extensively on natural history and medicine. Her works Physica and Causae et Curae documented the medicinal properties of plants, animals, and minerals, making her one of the most important medical writers of the medieval period. She also composed music and wrote on theology.
timeline: Born in Bermersheim, Holy Roman Empire

name: James Lovelock
summary: James Lovelock was a British scientist who proposed the Gaia hypothesis, suggesting Earth functions as a self-regulating system. He invented the electron capture detector, which enabled the detection of CFCs and pesticides in the atmosphere. His detector provided the data that led to the discovery of the ozone hole. He died on his 103rd birthday.
timeline: Earned PhD from London School of Hygiene
Proposed Gaia hypothesis with Lynn Margulis
Published 'Gaia: A New Look at Life on Earth'

name: Lynn Margulis
summary: Lynn Margulis was an American biologist who developed the endosymbiotic theory, proving that mitochondria and chloroplasts in eukaryotic cells originated as free-living bacteria. Her theory, initially rejected 15 times before publication, is now considered one of the most important advances in cell biology. She also collaborated with James Lovelock on the Gaia hypothesis.
timeline: Theory gradually accepted by scientific community
Co-developed Gaia hypothesis with James Lovelock
Elected to National Academy of Sciences

name: Santiago Ramon y Cajal
summary: Santiago Ramón y Cajal was a Spanish neuroscientist who is considered the father of modern neuroscience. He used Golgi's staining method to prove that the nervous system consists of individual neurons rather than a continuous network (neuron doctrine). He shared the 1906 Nobel Prize with Camillo Golgi. His detailed drawings of neural structures remain iconic.
timeline: Born in Petilla de Aragón, Spain
Earned medical degree from University of Zaragoza
Proved neuron doctrine using Golgi stain
Published textbook of the nervous system
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Paul Dirac
summary: Paul Dirac was a British theoretical physicist who formulated the Dirac equation, which predicted the existence of antimatter. He shared the 1933 Nobel Prize in Physics for his contributions to quantum mechanics. The Dirac equation unified quantum mechanics and special relativity and predicted the positron, which was discovered experimentally in 1932.

name: Max Planck
summary: Max Planck was a German physicist who originated quantum theory by discovering that energy is emitted in discrete packets called quanta. His 1900 paper introducing Planck's constant and the quantum of action launched the quantum revolution in physics. He won the 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics. The Planck constant is one of the fundamental constants of nature.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Munich
Introduced quantum theory with Planck's constant
Became president of Kaiser Wilhelm Society
Son executed for role in plot against Hitler

name: Richard Feynman
summary: Richard Feynman was an American theoretical physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to quantum electrodynamics (QED), for which he shared the 1965 Nobel Prize in Physics. He developed Feynman diagrams, the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics, and was known for his exceptional teaching ability. He also investigated the Challenger disaster.
timeline: Worked on Manhattan Project at Los Alamos
Identified O-ring failure in Challenger investigation
